reviews.review_msg: Wow. Someone didn't get the marks they wanted! The Myth and Communication course with Roman was the most interesting one i took in that department, and Steve's tutorials ruled. Really, the best tutorials i have had. In a sea of self-important professors at SFU, i would say he was the least self-important. Like the opposite of self important.
Ladies, don't go to his office hour alone, is all I'm saying. Entirely useless, self-important, and lusty man. Disgusting!
Make sure you keep up with the weekly readings because it's very very heavy. As long as you do and take some notes, you should be fine.

Her textbook is really worth to read. The readings that she compiled are many but interesting. The study guide she wrote is fantastic. The course demands one to be always on top of the readings. If one is on time, there is no problem of flunking! I loved this course.
I had a fair TA so for me, the course is pretty easy...EXCEPT the super hard final! However, it isn't hard to get a B. Ian seems like a nice guy
The TA's were bad.  I was wondering who chose the TA for this course.  I was also wondering if this is a year 3 English course or a communication course.

the TA's are horrible! I wont mention names but she was absolutely horrible, she was an english nazi, everyone i know had bad feedback on their papers and she suggest "english workshops" bleh! Ian is passionate, but veryyy boring. TA's are horrible.

I am not sure who picks the teacher assistant for the course, but lets just say that evidently they were more concerned with essay foramt then essay content.  Do not take the class unless you are destined to determine your tolerance to irrelevant course asignments to boring course readings.

lets just say i dropped it. the assignments are so flakey and the readings are ancient and boring.. who wants to read more than one chapter on copyrighting.. bleh! 372 was better, but still was not one of my fav cmns classes.

I also felt the assignments had vague instructions and were very poorly related to the course material. Material was uninteresting - moreso than I expected. If you have to choose between this and Ian's other dist. ed. course, CMNS 372, I'd recommend 372
The instructions for the assignments are not well defined.  It is difficult to understand the link of how the course material relates to the assignments.
